title: Netflix Reaches Streaming Deal for ‘Seinfeld’
text:
Netflix Inc. is losing streaming rights to “Friends” but —yada yada yada—now it is getting rights to “Seinfeld.”

The company has struck a five-year deal with Sony Pictures Television to become the exclusive world-wide streaming home of “Seinfeld,” the hit NBC comedy from the 1990s about four friends in Manhattan that was often jokingly described as “a show about nothing.”

Episodes of “Seinfeld” will move to Netflix in 2021 from their current home, Walt Disney Co. ’s Hulu.

The deal comes at a crucial time for Netflix, as it is set to lose some of its other iconic reruns in coming years. The sitcom “Friends” is moving to AT&T Inc. ’s WarnerMedia next year, while “The Office” will head to NBCUniversal in 2021—in both cases to be featured in streaming services the companies plan to launch.

share your thoughts How will the moves of these popular shows affect your streaming subscription decisions? Join the conversation below.

Terms of the “Seinfeld” deal, which was first reported by the Los Angeles Times, weren’t disclosed. In 2015, Hulu reached an agreement with “Seinfeld” distributor Sony Pictures Television, a unit of Sony Corp., for U.S. rights to the show for six years valued at $130 million, a person close to the matter said.

The price tag for Netflix’s acquisition of “Seinfeld” is likely higher, people familiar with the matter said, because it includes international rights.

Netflix has a big lead in the streaming-video wars, with some 150 million global subscribers. But it faces some challenges as new entrants arrive in the industry, some with lower-priced services. In its most recent quarter, the company lost U.S. subscribers for the first time in nearly a decade.

Netflix has invested heavily in original programming, but its viewers spend a large portion of their time watching classic hits in its library, according to Nielsen data. The price for popular old shows is on the rise as new streaming services Disney, WarnerMedia and Comcast Corp ,’s NBCUniversal are all launching in the next several months.

NBCUniversal recently agreed to a five-year deal for “The Office” valued at $500 million while WarnerMedia landed streaming rights to “Friends” for five years at $425 million. The “Seinfeld” deal exceeds either of those pacts, a person with knowledge of the matter said, showing that Netflix is willing to pay a hefty price for certain properties.

Reruns of “Seinfeld” will still be available on local TV stations and the WarnerMedia cable channel TBS. The show has already made more than $3 billion in global rerun deals, an executive close to the show said.

Besides Sony and “Seinfeld” creators Jerry Seinfeld and Larry David, other beneficiaries of the new deal include WarnerMedia, which became a financial stakeholder in the program when it acquired Castle Rock, the company that produced “Seinfeld.”

Related Video Disney, AT&T and Comcast have plans to enter the streaming-video ring, armed with well-known TV and movie brands. But can they hold their own against industry juggernaut Netflix? Photo illustration: Heather Seidel/The Wall Street Journal

Write to Joe Flint at joe.flint@wsj.com
description: Netflix has struck a five-year deal to become the exclusive world-wide streaming home of “Seinfeld,” the hit NBC comedy from the 1990s.
